body: Btw. short update. Given I could not determine anything anymore in the Ajax codebase itself on my side from the ajax TCKs, I would say the code is merge ready. Question is can we merge? The official TCKs still use htmlunit so they cannot run against the new codebase, and the challenge and pr I have offered to fix this has not been picked up yet!
I agree this PR has been open for a long time.

Yes the downside I see is, if we merge now we lose tck testability, until the tck gets updated to selenium. This might be a problem for companies requiring full TCK compliance (IBM comes to my mind)
We might have to go the extra mile and make both implementations switchable. Something I would love to avoid due to the double maintenance this involves.
On the other hand if this code now is sticking in limbo ad infinitum, i have the double maintenance headache anyway and given atm I do not have to work on projects I can spend a lot of time, which I later wont have again once I am reassigned.
Yikes OK then I will leave it up to @tandraschko @volosied what they want to do.  Sounds like this could be tricky/messy.

Yes thats the reason why I started with the selenium port of the TCK to begin with, to get the tests out of the tech dead end they obviously have been for quite a while. Selenium simply is under active development and has strong corporate backing.
Whether the Jakarta is going to pick up  the PR or not, good question, but so far I have not seen any significant feedback.
Hi, let me find out if there's been any progress or testing done with the Selenium TCK PR (1732) yet.
Thanks for the reviews. The user who reported this error says they encountered some problem with this fix. Not sure why, but I'm trying to get more information from them before I merge.

Hi I just noticed i ported from a rather old branch (4.0.1) there have been many bugfixes going into the TCK, so I will have te Re-port again and update the pull request accordingly. This will happen until sometime next week.
(we have a holiday tomorrow)
not a big deal but a little bit of work. With that I also can add my latest base framework which has a few smaller fixes over the PR I offered for the TCK.
(already added a comment, that they should postpone until next week for that), but nevertheless an info would be nice if they would be willing to add selenium based tck tests at least optionally.
So that we can test as well from the official tck codebase! I cannot do more than to hand over the ported code to them. I am not a comitter on their side.
will reissue the pull request, needs more testing because, in the resource handler also code musst be merged in from nect

a reproducer would be great for such issues
we have a simple primefaces-test project which runs with all mojarra+myfaces versions on jetty
quite easy to replicate it something

did you run the integration tests? we have some of them which tests servlets mappings
otherwise we have to fix them first
I personally like this change!
added https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MYFACES-4040... independent of the original fix, but dependend from the updated codebases in 2.3 and 2.3-NEXT

Note, if you still need the i18n, use 
        <h:outputScript pr:nonce="test123"  name="faces-i18n.js" library="myfaces" target="head"/>
will reopen it later when i have wrapped up 4526
@volosied please review, I do not want to merge before you give the ok!
I will resolve the conflicts next week, they are related to my work on MYFACES-4526, MYFACES-4040

Also i will merge the port of this fix down up to 2.3-next on monday!
Question is, do we want the fix also for 2.3 or does next only suffice?
@werpu I really appreciate all your work on this!
@tandraschko  What do you mean? The CI build passed, as well as my local build.  TCK looks better now, too.

If you check our root pom, integration Tests are excluded from build currently
We need to fix then
These look good to me thanks for the PR.  They might want you to open a JIRA ticket if you have not already so we can track this fix.

@melloware Thanks for the heads up.  I created the issue here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MYFACES-4528
Sorry, should have done that first.  This is my first commit to this community and didn't realize you were using Jira

This looks good -- just tested locally. Thanks for providing a patch and making the JIRA.

Related to which, I think the community should create an issues tab to allow users to create issues in this repo since JIRA is disabled for new signups.  We can follow on on this later.

Just tested -- looks great! Thank you.  However, could you fix up the commit message?  It's a bit confusing with the revert revert beginning. 

I don't have a strong opinion about 2.3. Let me see what @pnicolucci says.

All green 🚀

I actually prefer GitHub Issues myself but yes an easy way for users to report issue we can always make a JIRA ticket if we discover its a real issue
Also does this fix need to be backported to 2.3 and 2.3-next?

wrong branch, already merged
closing it, could restore the old pull request
Says there are conflicts?

Just a short explanation. This is not a full backport of the entire next javascript rendering infrastructure, just a small fix which shifts the parameters around just like the other fixes do, but within the code of 2.3.x: Example: ```html Click here ```` If you check the params are now passed under the params attribute. and so is the javax.faces.behavior.event (which is a request parameter)

Tests have passed... I will leave it up to you whether you want to take it in, but given we have synchronized our myfaces jsf.js codebases now back from next into the original codebase, I highly can recommend to take this also in and consider this bug fixed for all of 2.3+
@pnicolucci
I think so. It's a fairly simple fix and should apply easily to those branches.
@werpu @volosied  I don't have an objection to backporting this one.

weird, works on localhsot
@melloware would you like to check it?
I can take a look.

Ok I will merge the code then into 2.3, thanks for the update.
Also @pnicolucci I have merged the jsf.js 2.3-next codebase back into 2.3, this however means we cut browser support for browsers below IE9.
If there are any objections to this - I know you guys have a ton of customers, so a change in a stable branch might be too much, I will revert this change.

The codebase is more or less the same but it has dropped a ton of ie6 and 7 and even older browser code, and introduced a construct in a fixed head replace (there was a tck issue this has fixed) which relies on a dom construct which ie9+ only support.

> Ok I will merge the code then into 2.3, thanks for the update. Also @pnicolucci I have merged the jsf.js 2.3-next codebase back into 2.3, this however means we cut browser support for browsers below IE9. If there are any objections to this - I know you guys have a ton of customers, so a change in a stable branch might be too much, I will revert this change.
> 
> The codebase is more or less the same but it has dropped a ton of ie6 and 7 and even older browser code, and introduced a construct in a fixed head replace (there was a tck issue this has fixed) which relies on a dom construct which ie9+ only support.

@werpu I think this requires more of a broad community discussion on the mailing list. The last I saw I thought the decision was to only update the 4.0 (potentially 2.3-next) code base and to potentially backport to previously released versions with a context parameter. I'd like to see a vote so we can ensure everyone is on board with the decision, pros/cons, and default of any such context parameter. I'm fine with backporting fixes, however, removing support for browsers etc IMO warrants a more detailed discussion. My personal opinion is we err on the side of caution.
I have started an informal vote on the mailing list to get a general community opinion about it.

Hi I have reopened the tck ajax pull request, this time against the proper branch https://github.com/jakartaee/faces/pull/1770

Lets see if they take it in!

```
org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationSessionCookieConfig 
does not define or inherit an implementation of the resolved method 
abstract java.lang.String getAttribute(java.lang.String)' of interface jakarta.servlet.SessionCookieConfig.
```

@melloware  It looks like the layout=list was only added to 4.0 (per the spec). I thought it was added to 2.3-next, but was mistaken. So no need to backport.

Closing in favor of: https://github.com/apache/myfaces/pull/443
Excellent work!
Thank you!

Thanks for pointing that out. I noticed that we always write the id in the `"partial-response` tag, but Mojarra only writes it under the condition you pointed above (viewroot instanceof NamingContainer). However, this leads to a problem because Mojarra seems to be out of compliance here per the schema here: https://jakarta.ee/xml/ns/jakartaee/web-partialresponse_4_0.xsd ``` [

The “partial-response” element is the root of the partial response information hierarchy, and contains nested elements for all possible elements that can exist in the response.

This element must have an “id” attribute whose value is the return from calling getContainerClientId() on the UIViewRoot to which this response pertains.

``` _"This element must have an “id” attribute whose value is the return from calling getContainerClientId() on the UIViewRoot to which this response pertains. "_ Mojarra should write it every time, not just in some cases. The question becomes how can view know if the viewroot is an instance of NamingContainer in the ajax responses. Currently (RC2), we don't. We only render `name="jakarta.faces.ViewState"`.  This PR prefixes with the id (via Java) now so it looks more like: `name="j_id__v_0:jakarta.faces.ViewState"`. 

However, it doesn't address the cases where the input is rendered via JavaScript.  After an Ajax response, the updated form has  `name="jakarta.faces.ViewState"` again.

The javascript would then extract the boolean to determine whether to prefix the container id to the jakarta.faces.viewstate in the name attribute of name. 

The later two commits are a bit of a mess.  I'm not sure how exact namedViewRoot from the ajax response.  I tried `partials.namedViewRoot` and `partials.attributes.getAttribute("namedViewRoot")`. Neither works. :( 

Thanks for your help in advance!

### Short Explanation Sorry for jumping in so late, I have not had that on my radar... To answer the question, the only way to determine the viewRootId atm. is by checking the ViewState update identifier to my knowledge in the ajax response/ or if you need it earlier, in the form. Thats what we are doing for determining it on the form side: ```javascript export function resolveViewId(form: DQ): string { const viewState = form.querySelectorAll(`input[type='hidden'][name*='${$nsp(P_VIEWSTATE)}']`).id.orElse("").value; const divider = $faces().separatorchar; const viewId = viewState.split(divider, 2)[0]; const viewStateViewId = viewId.indexOf($nsp(P_VIEWSTATE)) === -1 ? viewId : ""; // myfaces specific, we in non portlet environments prepend the viewId // even without being in a naming container, the other components ignore that return form.id.value.indexOf(viewStateViewId) === 0 ? viewStateViewId : ""; } ``` (or in a backported implementation on the old codebase) So the fix itself if you do not want to challenge the spec (See below longer explanation why that probably is necessary) simply is a) roll the identifier for ViewState and client id also in the name on the javascript side (both things are a one liner) b) also do the same for the name attributes on the java side (for the non ajax case) This might cause problem however because the code expects a raw jakarta.faces.ViewState as post value as per spec (see below longer explanation). --- ### Longer Explanation and why the test might be pointless The JSDOC spec says: Thats basically what we implement in our javascripts. So in order to prefix whatever we have.. we just use the same name as the id (with or without the unique, number, does not make too much of a difference)... On the other hand.. in the submit request the viewstate is always passed down only as javax.faces.ViewState as per spec as per JSDoc: So the server expects a jakarta.faces.ViewState key not <namingContainer>:jakarta.faces.ViewState. This can be worked out for the ajax case by doing a remapping before the xhr post, but for the non Ajax case where the input values and names are pushed down as they are this will not work! We probably have to offer a challenge here, before starting to fix anything. The test might be wrong here or at least shooting over the top! Eiter way for me it is clear I can determine that we are in a named scenario, if a prefix for a naming container is present in the update for the ViewState element, the only requirement I have is that this naming container must be determinable one way or the other on the page (if I cannot determine it, I have to guess the entire page is the naming container, portlets have clear naming container boundaries marked via identifiers)
